intro: Mimulus clevelandii, commonly known as the Cleveland's monkeyflower, is a species native to the western United States. It is a herbaceous annual or biennial plant with striking orange to red flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils along streambanks and in open woodlands. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while its stems are upright and branched. Mimulus clevelandii plays an important role in supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
